My interview experience with Goldman Sachs for the SDE-2 (Associate Software Engineer) role:There was an online assessment and a phone screening round comprising of medium and hard DSA problems prior to the onsite rounds. The onsite interviews were interesting and different from traditional ones. Each round had two interviewers who actively cross-questioned me, so the pressure was a bit high.Onsite Round 1: DSA Round â€“ Two LeetCode medium problems + one follow-up question.Onsite Round 2: Software Engineering Practices Round â€“ This was the most interesting round. I was grilled on my current projects, HLD of rate limiting, different authentication strategies, REST vs GraphQL, JSON vs Protobuf, Java internals, and Java OOP concepts.Onsite Round 3: Design Round â€“ I was asked about the LLD of a flight booking service, database choice questions, and designing a service to validate millions of records from a text file (without using data processing frameworks like Spark). There were also questions on multithreading, concurrency, and Java.Onsite Round 4: Hiring Manager Round â€“ Focused on my resume, projects, and general behavioral questions.I felt I hadnâ€™t performed well, but to my surprise, I cleared all the rounds!In hindsight, what worked for me was:1. Staying calm and not panicking over unfamiliar questions.2. Even though I hadnâ€™t revised Java or design topics, I thought logically about what the correct behavior should be and answered accordingly.3. Most importantly, I treated each interview as a learning opportunity and turned them into engaging discussions.You either win or you learn!hashtag#interview hashtag#goldmansachs hashtag#softwareengineer

My interview experience with Goldman Sachs for the SDE-2 (Associate Software Engineer) role:There was an online assessment and a phone screening round comprising of medium and hard DSA problems prior to the onsite rounds. The onsite interviews were interesting and different from traditional ones. Each round had two interviewers who actively cross-questioned me, so the pressure was a bit high.Onsite Round 1: DSA Round â€“ Two LeetCode medium problems + one follow-up question.Onsite Round 2: Software Engineering Practices Round â€“ This was the most interesting round. I was grilled on my current projects, HLD of rate limiting, different authentication strategies, REST vs GraphQL, JSON vs Protobuf, Java internals, and Java OOP concepts.Onsite Round 3: Design Round â€“ I was asked about the LLD of a flight booking service, database choice questions, and designing a service to validate millions of records from a text file (without using data processing frameworks like Spark). There were also questions on multithreading, concurrency, and Java.Onsite Round 4: Hiring Manager Round â€“ Focused on my resume, projects, and general behavioral questions.I felt I hadnâ€™t performed well, but to my surprise, I cleared all the rounds!In hindsight, what worked for me was:1. Staying calm and not panicking over unfamiliar questions.2. Even though I hadnâ€™t revised Java or design topics, I thought logically about what the correct behavior should be and answered accordingly.3. Most importantly, I treated each interview as a learning opportunity and turned them into engaging discussions.You either win or you learn!hashtag#interview hashtag#goldmansachs hashtag#softwareengineer

Rethinking Recruiting: Beyond Resumes and InterviewsIn the world of talent acquisition, two critical questions should drive every hiring decision:1. Can this candidate consistently deliver exceptional results?2. Do they possess the intrinsic motivation and agency to excel?Traditional recruiting methodsâ€”endless resume screenings and standard interviewsâ€”often miss the mark. The most effective approaches are surprisingly straightforward:1. Seek authentic insights from past colleagues who can vouch for the candidate's real-world performance2. Implement meaningful trial periods that reveal true work capabilities and cultural fitThink of hiring like a high-stakes relationship: you're not just filling a role, but finding a strategic partner who can dramatically elevate your team's performance.The productivity gap between top and mediocre knowledge workers is staggeringâ€”sometimes 10-100x. Conversely, a poor hire can significantly erode team effectiveness. As AI continues to transform workforce dynamics, the premium on human excellence has never been higher.In the age of LLMs, asking the right questions matters more than having all the answers prepared.hashtag#Recruiting hashtag#TalentAcquisition hashtag#ProfessionalDevelopment hashtag#WorkplaceTrends

My interview experience with Goldman Sachs for the SDE-2 (Associate Software Engineer) role:There was an online assessment and a phone screening round comprising of medium and hard DSA problems prior to the onsite rounds. The onsite interviews were interesting and different from traditional ones. Each round had two interviewers who actively cross-questioned me, so the pressure was a bit high.Onsite Round 1: DSA Round â€“ Two LeetCode medium problems + one follow-up question.Onsite Round 2: Software Engineering Practices Round â€“ This was the most interesting round. I was grilled on my current projects, HLD of rate limiting, different authentication strategies, REST vs GraphQL, JSON vs Protobuf, Java internals, and Java OOP concepts.Onsite Round 3: Design Round â€“ I was asked about the LLD of a flight booking service, database choice questions, and designing a service to validate millions of records from a text file (without using data processing frameworks like Spark). There were also questions on multithreading, concurrency, and Java.Onsite Round 4: Hiring Manager Round â€“ Focused on my resume, projects, and general behavioral questions.I felt I hadnâ€™t performed well, but to my surprise, I cleared all the rounds!In hindsight, what worked for me was:1. Staying calm and not panicking over unfamiliar questions.2. Even though I hadnâ€™t revised Java or design topics, I thought logically about what the correct behavior should be and answered accordingly.3. Most importantly, I treated each interview as a learning opportunity and turned them into engaging discussions.You either win or you learn!hashtag#interview hashtag#goldmansachs hashtag#softwareengineer

My interview experience with Goldman Sachs for the SDE-2 (Associate Software Engineer) role:There was an online assessment and a phone screening round comprising of medium and hard DSA problems prior to the onsite rounds. The onsite interviews were interesting and different from traditional ones. Each round had two interviewers who actively cross-questioned me, so the pressure was a bit high.Onsite Round 1: DSA Round â€“ Two LeetCode medium problems + one follow-up question.Onsite Round 2: Software Engineering Practices Round â€“ This was the most interesting round. I was grilled on my current projects, HLD of rate limiting, different authentication strategies, REST vs GraphQL, JSON vs Protobuf, Java internals, and Java OOP concepts.Onsite Round 3: Design Round â€“ I was asked about the LLD of a flight booking service, database choice questions, and designing a service to validate millions of records from a text file (without using data processing frameworks like Spark). There were also questions on multithreading, concurrency, and Java.Onsite Round 4: Hiring Manager Round â€“ Focused on my resume, projects, and general behavioral questions.I felt I hadnâ€™t performed well, but to my surprise, I cleared all the rounds!In hindsight, what worked for me was:1. Staying calm and not panicking over unfamiliar questions.2. Even though I hadnâ€™t revised Java or design topics, I thought logically about what the correct behavior should be and answered accordingly.3. Most importantly, I treated each interview as a learning opportunity and turned them into engaging discussions.You either win or you learn!hashtag#interview hashtag#goldmansachs hashtag#softwareengineer

My interview experience with Goldman Sachs for the SDE-2 (Associate Software Engineer) role:There was an online assessment and a phone screening round comprising of medium and hard DSA problems prior to the onsite rounds. The onsite interviews were interesting and different from traditional ones. Each round had two interviewers who actively cross-questioned me, so the pressure was a bit high.Onsite Round 1: DSA Round â€“ Two LeetCode medium problems + one follow-up question.Onsite Round 2: Software Engineering Practices Round â€“ This was the most interesting round. I was grilled on my current projects, HLD of rate limiting, different authentication strategies, REST vs GraphQL, JSON vs Protobuf, Java internals, and Java OOP concepts.Onsite Round 3: Design Round â€“ I was asked about the LLD of a flight booking service, database choice questions, and designing a service to validate millions of records from a text file (without using data processing frameworks like Spark). There were also questions on multithreading, concurrency, and Java.Onsite Round 4: Hiring Manager Round â€“ Focused on my resume, projects, and general behavioral questions.I felt I hadnâ€™t performed well, but to my surprise, I cleared all the rounds!In hindsight, what worked for me was:1. Staying calm and not panicking over unfamiliar questions.2. Even though I hadnâ€™t revised Java or design topics, I thought logically about what the correct behavior should be and answered accordingly.3. Most importantly, I treated each interview as a learning opportunity and turned them into engaging discussions.You either win or you learn!hashtag#interview hashtag#goldmansachs hashtag#softwareengineer

Rethinking Recruiting: Beyond Resumes and InterviewsIn the world of talent acquisition, two critical questions should drive every hiring decision:1. Can this candidate consistently deliver exceptional results?2. Do they possess the intrinsic motivation and agency to excel?Traditional recruiting methodsâ€”endless resume screenings and standard interviewsâ€”often miss the mark. The most effective approaches are surprisingly straightforward:1. Seek authentic insights from past colleagues who can vouch for the candidate's real-world performance2. Implement meaningful trial periods that reveal true work capabilities and cultural fitThink of hiring like a high-stakes relationship: you're not just filling a role, but finding a strategic partner who can dramatically elevate your team's performance.The productivity gap between top and mediocre knowledge workers is staggeringâ€”sometimes 10-100x. Conversely, a poor hire can significantly erode team effectiveness. I remember when I was running stores, hiring was all about people, not just paper. Iâ€™d use resumes to filter candidates and schedule interviewsâ€”but once we got to the interview, I never looked at the resume.Why? Because by that point, I wasnâ€™t interested in what was on paperâ€”I wanted to get to know the person. Anyone can pay someone to write a great resume (heck, Iâ€™ve helped plenty of people with theirs). But you canâ€™t hire someone to take the interview for you.Use resumes to schedule the interview. But when itâ€™s time to hire, interview the person.hashtag#Hiring hashtag#Leadership hashtag#InterviewTips

Have you ever been told that your procurement experience doesnâ€™t align with a recruiterâ€™s industry requirements?Itâ€™s unfortunate how often talented professionals are overlooked simply because they havenâ€™t worked in a specific industry.â€œSorry, weâ€™re looking for someone with experience in Food & Beverageâ€¦ Constructionâ€¦ Oil & Gasâ€¦ Healthcareâ€¦â€Sound familiar?Procurement skills are highly transferable. The ability to negotiate, manage suppliers, optimize costs, and drive efficiency isnâ€™t limited to one industry. By narrowing the talent pool based on sector experience alone, recruiters may be missing out on exceptional candidates who bring fresh perspectives, stronger procurement expertise, and a track record of delivering results.Instead of dismissing candidates outright, take the time to review their experience holistically. If their background is strong and their skills align with the role, give them a chance. After all, the hiring process is about finding the best fitâ€”why not start by expanding the possibilities?Be open. Be strategic. The right talent might be outside the box youâ€™ve drawn.We are Procurement. We outsource everything.hashtag#ProcurementOfficershashtag#ProcurementProfessionalshashtag#HiringProcurementhashtag#RecruitmentProfessionals

My interview experience with Goldman Sachs for the SDE-2 (Associate Software Engineer) role:There was an online assessment and a phone screening round comprising of medium and hard DSA problems prior to the onsite rounds. The onsite interviews were interesting and different from traditional ones. Each round had two interviewers who actively cross-questioned me, so the pressure was a bit high.Onsite Round 1: DSA Round â€“ Two LeetCode medium problems + one follow-up question.Onsite Round 2: Software Engineering Practices Round â€“ This was the most interesting round. I was grilled on my current projects, HLD of rate limiting, different authentication strategies, REST vs GraphQL, JSON vs Protobuf, Java internals, and Java OOP concepts.Onsite Round 3: Design Round â€“ I was asked about the LLD of a flight booking service, database choice questions, and designing a service to validate millions of records from a text file (without using data processing frameworks like Spark). There were also questions on multithreading, concurrency, and Java.Onsite Round 4: Hiring Manager Round â€“ Focused on my resume, projects, and general behavioral questions.I felt I hadnâ€™t performed well, but to my surprise, I cleared all the rounds!In hindsight, what worked for me was:1. Staying calm and not panicking over unfamiliar questions.2. Even though I hadnâ€™t revised Java or design topics, I thought logically about what the correct behavior should be and answered accordingly.3. Most importantly, I treated each interview as a learning opportunity and turned them into engaging discussions.You either win or you learn!hashtag#interview hashtag#goldmansachs hashtag#softwareengineer

Can this candidate consistently deliver exceptional results?2. Do they possess the intrinsic motivation and agency to excel?Traditional recruiting methodsâ€”endless resume screenings and standard interviewsâ€”often miss the mark. My interview experience with Goldman Sachs for the SDE-2 (Associate Software Engineer) role:There was an online assessment and a phone screening round comprising of medium and hard DSA problems prior to the onsite rounds. The onsite interviews were interesting and different from traditional ones. Each round had two interviewers who actively cross-questioned me, so the pressure was a bit high.Onsite Round 1: DSA Round â€“ Two LeetCode medium problems + one follow-up question.Onsite Round 2: Software Engineering Practices Round â€“ This was the most interesting round. I was grilled on my current projects, HLD of rate limiting, different authentication strategies, REST vs GraphQL, JSON vs Protobuf, Java internals, and Java OOP concepts.Onsite Round 3: Design Round â€“ I was asked about the LLD of a flight booking service, database choice questions, and designing a service to validate millions of records from a text file (without using data processing frameworks like Spark). There were also questions on multithreading, concurrency, and Java.Onsite Round 4: Hiring Manager Round â€“ Focused on my resume, projects, and general behavioral questions.I felt I hadnâ€™t performed well, but to my surprise, I cleared all the rounds!In hindsight, what worked for me was:1. Staying calm and not panicking over unfamiliar questions.2. Even though I hadnâ€™t revised Java or design topics, I thought logically about what the correct behavior should be and answered accordingly.3. Most importantly, I treated each interview as a learning opportunity and turned them into engaging discussions.You either win or you learn!hashtag#interview hashtag#goldmansachs hashtag#softwareengineer

My interview experience with Goldman Sachs for the SDE-2 (Associate Software Engineer) role:There was an online assessment and a phone screening round comprising of medium and hard DSA problems prior to the onsite rounds. The onsite interviews were interesting and different from traditional ones. Each round had two interviewers who actively cross-questioned me, so the pressure was a bit high.Onsite Round 1: DSA Round â€“ Two LeetCode medium problems + one follow-up question.Onsite Round 2: Software Engineering Practices Round â€“ This was the most interesting round. I was grilled on my current projects, HLD of rate limiting, different authentication strategies, REST vs GraphQL, JSON vs Protobuf, Java internals, and Java OOP concepts.Onsite Round 3: Design Round â€“ I was asked about the LLD of a flight booking service, database choice questions, and designing a service to validate millions of records from a text file (without using data processing frameworks like Spark). There were also questions on multithreading, concurrency, and Java.Onsite Round 4: Hiring Manager Round â€“ Focused on my resume, projects, and general behavioral questions.I felt I hadnâ€™t performed well, but to my surprise, I cleared all the rounds!In hindsight, what worked for me was:1. Staying calm and not panicking over unfamiliar questions.2. Even though I hadnâ€™t revised Java or design topics, I thought logically about what the correct behavior should be and answered accordingly.3. Most importantly, I treated each interview as a learning opportunity and turned them into engaging discussions.You either win or you learn!hashtag#interview hashtag#goldmansachs hashtag#softwareengineer

I remember when I was running stores, hiring was all about people, not just paper. Iâ€™d use resumes to filter candidates and schedule interviewsâ€”but once we got to the interview, I never looked at the resume.Why? Because by that point, I wasnâ€™t interested in what was on paperâ€”I wanted to get to know the person. Anyone can pay someone to write a great resume (heck, Iâ€™ve helped plenty of people with theirs). But you canâ€™t hire someone to take the interview for you.Use resumes to schedule the interview. Have you ever been told that your procurement experience doesnâ€™t align with a recruiterâ€™s industry requirements?Itâ€™s unfortunate how often talented professionals are overlooked simply because they havenâ€™t worked in a specific industry.â€œSorry, weâ€™re looking for someone with experience in Food & Beverageâ€¦ Constructionâ€¦ Oil & Gasâ€¦ Healthcareâ€¦â€Sound familiar?Procurement skills are highly transferable. The ability to negotiate, manage suppliers, optimize costs, and drive efficiency isnâ€™t limited to one industry. By narrowing the talent pool based on sector experience alone, recruiters may be missing out on exceptional candidates who bring fresh perspectives, stronger procurement expertise, and a track record of delivering results.Instead of dismissing candidates outright, take the time to review their experience holistically. After all, the hiring process is about finding the best fitâ€”why not start by expanding the possibilities?Be open. Be strategic. My interview experience with Goldman Sachs for the SDE-2 (Associate Software Engineer) role:There was an online assessment and a phone screening round comprising of medium and hard DSA problems prior to the onsite rounds. The onsite interviews were interesting and different from traditional ones. Each round had two interviewers who actively cross-questioned me, so the pressure was a bit high.Onsite Round 1: DSA Round â€“ Two LeetCode medium problems + one follow-up question.Onsite Round 2: Software Engineering Practices Round â€“ This was the most interesting round. I was grilled on my current projects, HLD of rate limiting, different authentication strategies, REST vs GraphQL, JSON vs Protobuf, Java internals, and Java OOP concepts.Onsite Round 3: Design Round â€“ I was asked about the LLD of a flight booking service, database choice questions, and designing a service to validate millions of records from a text file (without using data processing frameworks like Spark). There were also questions on multithreading, concurrency, and Java.Onsite Round 4: Hiring Manager Round â€“ Focused on my resume, projects, and general behavioral questions.I felt I hadnâ€™t performed well, but to my surprise, I cleared all the rounds!In hindsight, what worked for me was:1. Staying calm and not panicking over unfamiliar questions.2. Even though I hadnâ€™t revised Java or design topics, I thought logically about what the correct behavior should be and answered accordingly.3. Most importantly, I treated each interview as a learning opportunity and turned them into engaging discussions.You either win or you learn!hashtag#interview hashtag#goldmansachs hashtag#softwareengineer

I remember when I was running stores, hiring was all about people, not just paper. Iâ€™d use resumes to filter candidates and schedule interviewsâ€”but once we got to the interview, I never looked at the resume.Why? Because by that point, I wasnâ€™t interested in what was on paperâ€”I wanted to get to know the person. Anyone can pay someone to write a great resume (heck, Iâ€™ve helped plenty of people with theirs). But you canâ€™t hire someone to take the interview for you.Use resumes to schedule the interview. But when itâ€™s time to hire, interview the person.hashtag#Hiring hashtag#Leadership hashtag#InterviewTips

Have you ever been told that your procurement experience doesnâ€™t align with a recruiterâ€™s industry requirements?Itâ€™s unfortunate how often talented professionals are overlooked simply because they havenâ€™t worked in a specific industry.â€œSorry, weâ€™re looking for someone with experience in Food & Beverageâ€¦ Constructionâ€¦ Oil & Gasâ€¦ Healthcareâ€¦â€Sound familiar?Procurement skills are highly transferable. The ability to negotiate, manage suppliers, optimize costs, and drive efficiency isnâ€™t limited to one industry. By narrowing the talent pool based on sector experience alone, recruiters may be missing out on exceptional candidates who bring fresh perspectives, stronger procurement expertise, and a track record of delivering results.Instead of dismissing candidates outright, take the time to review their experience holistically. If their background is strong and their skills align with the role, give them a chance. After all, the hiring process is about finding the best fitâ€”why not start by expanding the possibilities?Be open. Be strategic. The right talent might be outside the box youâ€™ve drawn.We are Procurement. We outsource everything.hashtag#ProcurementOfficershashtag#ProcurementProfessionalshashtag#HiringProcurementhashtag#RecruitmentProfessionals

My interview experience with Goldman Sachs for the SDE-2 (Associate Software Engineer) role:There was an online assessment and a phone screening round comprising of medium and hard DSA problems prior to the onsite rounds. The onsite interviews were interesting and different from traditional ones. Each round had two interviewers who actively cross-questioned me, so the pressure was a bit high.Onsite Round 1: DSA Round â€“ Two LeetCode medium problems + one follow-up question.Onsite Round 2: Software Engineering Practices Round â€“ This was the most interesting round. I was grilled on my current projects, HLD of rate limiting, different authentication strategies, REST vs GraphQL, JSON vs Protobuf, Java internals, and Java OOP concepts.Onsite Round 3: Design Round â€“ I was asked about the LLD of a flight booking service, database choice questions, and designing a service to validate millions of records from a text file (without using data processing frameworks like Spark). There were also questions on multithreading, concurrency, and Java.Onsite Round 4: Hiring Manager Round â€“ Focused on my resume, projects, and general behavioral questions.I felt I hadnâ€™t performed well, but to my surprise, I cleared all the rounds!In hindsight, what worked for me was:1. Staying calm and not panicking over unfamiliar questions.2. Even though I hadnâ€™t revised Java or design topics, I thought logically about what the correct behavior should be and answered accordingly.3. Most importantly, I treated each interview as a learning opportunity and turned them into engaging discussions.You either win or you learn!hashtag#interview hashtag#goldmansachs hashtag#softwareengineer

I remember when I was running stores, hiring was all about people, not just paper. Iâ€™d use resumes to filter candidates and schedule interviewsâ€”but once we got to the interview, I never looked at the resume.Why? Because by that point, I wasnâ€™t interested in what was on paperâ€”I wanted to get to know the person. Anyone can pay someone to write a great resume (heck, Iâ€™ve helped plenty of people with theirs). But you canâ€™t hire someone to take the interview for you.Use resumes to schedule the interview. But when itâ€™s time to hire, interview the person.hashtag#Hiring hashtag#Leadership hashtag#InterviewTips

Have you ever been told that your procurement experience doesnâ€™t align with a recruiterâ€™s industry requirements?Itâ€™s unfortunate how often talented professionals are overlooked simply because they havenâ€™t worked in a specific industry.â€œSorry, weâ€™re looking for someone with experience in Food & Beverageâ€¦ Constructionâ€¦ Oil & Gasâ€¦ Healthcareâ€¦â€Sound familiar?Procurement skills are highly transferable. The ability to negotiate, manage suppliers, optimize costs, and drive efficiency isnâ€™t limited to one industry. By narrowing the talent pool based on sector experience alone, recruiters may be missing out on exceptional candidates who bring fresh perspectives, stronger procurement expertise, and a track record of delivering results.Instead of dismissing candidates outright, take the time to review their experience holistically. If their background is strong and their skills align with the role, give them a chance. After all, the hiring process is about finding the best fitâ€”why not start by expanding the possibilities?Be open. Be strategic. The right talent might be outside the box youâ€™ve drawn.We are Procurement. We outsource everything.hashtag#ProcurementOfficershashtag#ProcurementProfessionalshashtag#HiringProcurementhashtag#RecruitmentProfessionals

My interview experience with Goldman Sachs for the SDE-2 (Associate Software Engineer) role:There was an online assessment and a phone screening round comprising of medium and hard DSA problems prior to the onsite rounds. The onsite interviews were interesting and different from traditional ones. Each round had two interviewers who actively cross-questioned me, so the pressure was a bit high.Onsite Round 1: DSA Round â€“ Two LeetCode medium problems + one follow-up question.Onsite Round 2: Software Engineering Practices Round â€“ This was the most interesting round. I was grilled on my current projects, HLD of rate limiting, different authentication strategies, REST vs GraphQL, JSON vs Protobuf, Java internals, and Java OOP concepts.Onsite Round 3: Design Round â€“ I was asked about the LLD of a flight booking service, database choice questions, and designing a service to validate millions of records from a text file (without using data processing frameworks like Spark). There were also questions on multithreading, concurrency, and Java.Onsite Round 4: Hiring Manager Round â€“ Focused on my resume, projects, and general behavioral questions.I felt I hadnâ€™t performed well, but to my surprise, I cleared all the rounds!In hindsight, what worked for me was:1. Staying calm and not panicking over unfamiliar questions.2. Even though I hadnâ€™t revised Java or design topics, I thought logically about what the correct behavior should be and answered accordingly.3. Most importantly, I treated each interview as a learning opportunity and turned them into engaging discussions.You either win or you learn!hashtag#interview hashtag#goldmansachs hashtag#softwareengineer

My interview experience with Goldman Sachs for the SDE-2 (Associate Software Engineer) role:There was an online assessment and a phone screening round comprising of medium and hard DSA problems prior to the onsite rounds. The onsite interviews were interesting and different from traditional ones. Each round had two interviewers who actively cross-questioned me, so the pressure was a bit high.Onsite Round 1: DSA Round â€“ Two LeetCode medium problems + one follow-up question.Onsite Round 2: Software Engineering Practices Round â€“ This was the most interesting round. I was grilled on my current projects, HLD of rate limiting, different authentication strategies, REST vs GraphQL, JSON vs Protobuf, Java internals, and Java OOP concepts.Onsite Round 3: Design Round â€“ I was asked about the LLD of a flight booking service, database choice questions, and designing a service to validate millions of records from a text file (without using data processing frameworks like Spark). There were also questions on multithreading, concurrency, and Java.Onsite Round 4: Hiring Manager Round â€“ Focused on my resume, projects, and general behavioral questions.I felt I hadnâ€™t performed well, but to my surprise, I cleared all the rounds!In hindsight, what worked for me was:1. Staying calm and not panicking over unfamiliar questions.2. Even though I hadnâ€™t revised Java or design topics, I thought logically about what the correct behavior should be and answered accordingly.3. Most importantly, I treated each interview as a learning opportunity and turned them into engaging discussions.You either win or you learn!hashtag#interview hashtag#goldmansachs hashtag#softwareengineer

My interview experience with Goldman Sachs for the SDE-2 (Associate Software Engineer) role:There was an online assessment and a phone screening round comprising of medium and hard DSA problems prior to the onsite rounds. The onsite interviews were interesting and different from traditional ones. Each round had two interviewers who actively cross-questioned me, so the pressure was a bit high.Onsite Round 1: DSA Round â€“ Two LeetCode medium problems + one follow-up question.Onsite Round 2: Software Engineering Practices Round â€“ This was the most interesting round. I was grilled on my current projects, HLD of rate limiting, different authentication strategies, REST vs GraphQL, JSON vs Protobuf, Java internals, and Java OOP concepts.Onsite Round 3: Design Round â€“ I was asked about the LLD of a flight booking service, database choice questions, and designing a service to validate millions of records from a text file (without using data processing frameworks like Spark). There were also questions on multithreading, concurrency, and Java.Onsite Round 4: Hiring Manager Round â€“ Focused on my resume, projects, and general behavioral questions.I felt I hadnâ€™t performed well, but to my surprise, I cleared all the rounds!In hindsight, what worked for me was:1. Staying calm and not panicking over unfamiliar questions.2. Even though I hadnâ€™t revised Java or design topics, I thought logically about what the correct behavior should be and answered accordingly.3. Most importantly, I treated each interview as a learning opportunity and turned them into engaging discussions.You either win or you learn!hashtag#interview hashtag#goldmansachs hashtag#softwareengineer

I remember when I was running stores, hiring was all about people, not just paper. Iâ€™d use resumes to filter candidates and schedule interviewsâ€”but once we got to the interview, I never looked at the resume.Why? Because by that point, I wasnâ€™t interested in what was on paperâ€”I wanted to get to know the person. Anyone can pay someone to write a great resume (heck, Iâ€™ve helped plenty of people with theirs). But you canâ€™t hire someone to take the interview for you.Use resumes to schedule the interview. But when itâ€™s time to hire, interview the person.hashtag#Hiring hashtag#Leadership hashtag#InterviewTips

Have you ever been told that your procurement experience doesnâ€™t align with a recruiterâ€™s industry requirements?Itâ€™s unfortunate how often talented professionals are overlooked simply because they havenâ€™t worked in a specific industry.â€œSorry, weâ€™re looking for someone with experience in Food & Beverageâ€¦ Constructionâ€¦ Oil & Gasâ€¦ Healthcareâ€¦â€Sound familiar?Procurement skills are highly transferable. The ability to negotiate, manage suppliers, optimize costs, and drive efficiency isnâ€™t limited to one industry. By narrowing the talent pool based on sector experience alone, recruiters may be missing out on exceptional candidates who bring fresh perspectives, stronger procurement expertise, and a track record of delivering results.Instead of dismissing candidates outright, take the time to review their experience holistically. If their background is strong and their skills align with the role, give them a chance. After all, the hiring process is about finding the best fitâ€”why not start by expanding the possibilities?Be open. Be strategic. The right talent might be outside the box youâ€™ve drawn.We are Procurement. We outsource everything.hashtag#ProcurementOfficershashtag#ProcurementProfessionalshashtag#HiringProcurementhashtag#RecruitmentProfessionals

My interview experience with Goldman Sachs for the SDE-2 (Associate Software Engineer) role:There was an online assessment and a phone screening round comprising of medium and hard DSA problems prior to the onsite rounds. The onsite interviews were interesting and different from traditional ones. Each round had two interviewers who actively cross-questioned me, so the pressure was a bit high.Onsite Round 1: DSA Round â€“ Two LeetCode medium problems + one follow-up question.Onsite Round 2: Software Engineering Practices Round â€“ This was the most interesting round. I was grilled on my current projects, HLD of rate limiting, different authentication strategies, REST vs GraphQL, JSON vs Protobuf, Java internals, and Java OOP concepts.Onsite Round 3: Design Round â€“ I was asked about the LLD of a flight booking service, database choice questions, and designing a service to validate millions of records from a text file (without using data processing frameworks like Spark). There were also questions on multithreading, concurrency, and Java.Onsite Round 4: Hiring Manager Round â€“ Focused on my resume, projects, and general behavioral questions.I felt I hadnâ€™t performed well, but to my surprise, I cleared all the rounds!In hindsight, what worked for me was:1. Staying calm and not panicking over unfamiliar questions.2. Even though I hadnâ€™t revised Java or design topics, I thought logically about what the correct behavior should be and answered accordingly.3. Most importantly, I treated each interview as a learning opportunity and turned them into engaging discussions.You either win or you learn!hashtag#interview hashtag#goldmansachs hashtag#softwareengineer

Can this candidate consistently deliver exceptional results?2. Do they possess the intrinsic motivation and agency to excel?Traditional recruiting methodsâ€”endless resume screenings and standard interviewsâ€”often miss the mark. The most effective approaches are surprisingly straightforward:1. Seek authentic insights from past colleagues who can vouch for the candidate's real-world performance2. Implement meaningful trial periods that reveal true work capabilities and cultural fitThink of hiring like a high-stakes relationship: you're not just filling a role, but finding a strategic partner who can dramatically elevate your team's performance.The productivity gap between top and mediocre knowledge workers is staggeringâ€”sometimes 10-100x. My interview experience with Goldman Sachs for the SDE-2 (Associate Software Engineer) role:There was an online assessment and a phone screening round comprising of medium and hard DSA problems prior to the onsite rounds. The onsite interviews were interesting and different from traditional ones. Each round had two interviewers who actively cross-questioned me, so the pressure was a bit high.Onsite Round 1: DSA Round â€“ Two LeetCode medium problems + one follow-up question.Onsite Round 2: Software Engineering Practices Round â€“ This was the most interesting round. I was grilled on my current projects, HLD of rate limiting, different authentication strategies, REST vs GraphQL, JSON vs Protobuf, Java internals, and Java OOP concepts.Onsite Round 3: Design Round â€“ I was asked about the LLD of a flight booking service, database choice questions, and designing a service to validate millions of records from a text file (without using data processing frameworks like Spark). There were also questions on multithreading, concurrency, and Java.Onsite Round 4: Hiring Manager Round â€“ Focused on my resume, projects, and general behavioral questions.I felt I hadnâ€™t performed well, but to my surprise, I cleared all the rounds!In hindsight, what worked for me was:1. Staying calm and not panicking over unfamiliar questions.2. Even though I hadnâ€™t revised Java or design topics, I thought logically about what the correct behavior should be and answered accordingly.3. Most importantly, I treated each interview as a learning opportunity and turned them into engaging discussions.You either win or you learn!hashtag#interview hashtag#goldmansachs hashtag#softwareengineer

My interview experience with Goldman Sachs for the SDE-2 (Associate Software Engineer) role:There was an online assessment and a phone screening round comprising of medium and hard DSA problems prior to the onsite rounds. The onsite interviews were interesting and different from traditional ones. Each round had two interviewers who actively cross-questioned me, so the pressure was a bit high.Onsite Round 1: DSA Round â€“ Two LeetCode medium problems + one follow-up question.Onsite Round 2: Software Engineering Practices Round â€“ This was the most interesting round. I was grilled on my current projects, HLD of rate limiting, different authentication strategies, REST vs GraphQL, JSON vs Protobuf, Java internals, and Java OOP concepts.Onsite Round 3: Design Round â€“ I was asked about the LLD of a flight booking service, database choice questions, and designing a service to validate millions of records from a text file (without using data processing frameworks like Spark). There were also questions on multithreading, concurrency, and Java.Onsite Round 4: Hiring Manager Round â€“ Focused on my resume, projects, and general behavioral questions.I felt I hadnâ€™t performed well, but to my surprise, I cleared all the rounds!In hindsight, what worked for me was:1. Staying calm and not panicking over unfamiliar questions.2. Even though I hadnâ€™t revised Java or design topics, I thought logically about what the correct behavior should be and answered accordingly.3. Most importantly, I treated each interview as a learning opportunity and turned them into engaging discussions.You either win or you learn!hashtag#interview hashtag#goldmansachs hashtag#softwareengineer

I remember when I was running stores, hiring was all about people, not just paper. Iâ€™d use resumes to filter candidates and schedule interviewsâ€”but once we got to the interview, I never looked at the resume.Why? Because by that point, I wasnâ€™t interested in what was on paperâ€”I wanted to get to know the person. Anyone can pay someone to write a great resume (heck, Iâ€™ve helped plenty of people with theirs). But you canâ€™t hire someone to take the interview for you.Use resumes to schedule the interview. But when itâ€™s time to hire, interview the person.hashtag#Hiring hashtag#Leadership hashtag#InterviewTips

Have you ever been told that your procurement experience doesnâ€™t align with a recruiterâ€™s industry requirements?Itâ€™s unfortunate how often talented professionals are overlooked simply because they havenâ€™t worked in a specific industry.â€œSorry, weâ€™re looking for someone with experience in Food & Beverageâ€¦ Constructionâ€¦ Oil & Gasâ€¦ Healthcareâ€¦â€Sound familiar?Procurement skills are highly transferable. The ability to negotiate, manage suppliers, optimize costs, and drive efficiency isnâ€™t limited to one industry. By narrowing the talent pool based on sector experience alone, recruiters may be missing out on exceptional candidates who bring fresh perspectives, stronger procurement expertise, and a track record of delivering results.Instead of dismissing candidates outright, take the time to review their experience holistically. If their background is strong and their skills align with the role, give them a chance. After all, the hiring process is about finding the best fitâ€”why not start by expanding the possibilities?Be open. Be strategic. The right talent might be outside the box youâ€™ve drawn.We are Procurement. We outsource everything.hashtag#ProcurementOfficershashtag#ProcurementProfessionalshashtag#HiringProcurementhashtag#RecruitmentProfessionals

My interview experience with Goldman Sachs for the SDE-2 (Associate Software Engineer) role:There was an online assessment and a phone screening round comprising of medium and hard DSA problems prior to the onsite rounds. The onsite interviews were interesting and different from traditional ones. Each round had two interviewers who actively cross-questioned me, so the pressure was a bit high.Onsite Round 1: DSA Round â€“ Two LeetCode medium problems + one follow-up question.Onsite Round 2: Software Engineering Practices Round â€“ This was the most interesting round. I was grilled on my current projects, HLD of rate limiting, different authentication strategies, REST vs GraphQL, JSON vs Protobuf, Java internals, and Java OOP concepts.Onsite Round 3: Design Round â€“ I was asked about the LLD of a flight booking service, database choice questions, and designing a service to validate millions of records from a text file (without using data processing frameworks like Spark). There were also questions on multithreading, concurrency, and Java.Onsite Round 4: Hiring Manager Round â€“ Focused on my resume, projects, and general behavioral questions.I felt I hadnâ€™t performed well, but to my surprise, I cleared all the rounds!In hindsight, what worked for me was:1. Staying calm and not panicking over unfamiliar questions.2. Even though I hadnâ€™t revised Java or design topics, I thought logically about what the correct behavior should be and answered accordingly.3. Most importantly, I treated each interview as a learning opportunity and turned them into engaging discussions.You either win or you learn!hashtag#interview hashtag#goldmansachs hashtag#softwareengineer

My interview experience with Goldman Sachs for the SDE-2 (Associate Software Engineer) role:There was an online assessment and a phone screening round comprising of medium and hard DSA problems prior to the onsite rounds. The onsite interviews were interesting and different from traditional ones. Each round had two interviewers who actively cross-questioned me, so the pressure was a bit high.Onsite Round 1: DSA Round â€“ Two LeetCode medium problems + one follow-up question.Onsite Round 2: Software Engineering Practices Round â€“ This was the most interesting round. I was grilled on my current projects, HLD of rate limiting, different authentication strategies, REST vs GraphQL, JSON vs Protobuf, Java internals, and Java OOP concepts.Onsite Round 3: Design Round â€“ I was asked about the LLD of a flight booking service, database choice questions, and designing a service to validate millions of records from a text file (without using data processing frameworks like Spark). There were also questions on multithreading, concurrency, and Java.Onsite Round 4: Hiring Manager Round â€“ Focused on my resume, projects, and general behavioral questions.I felt I hadnâ€™t performed well, but to my surprise, I cleared all the rounds!In hindsight, what worked for me was:1. Staying calm and not panicking over unfamiliar questions.2. Even though I hadnâ€™t revised Java or design topics, I thought logically about what the correct behavior should be and answered accordingly.3. Most importantly, I treated each interview as a learning opportunity and turned them into engaging discussions.You either win or you learn!hashtag#interview hashtag#goldmansachs hashtag#softwareengineer

My interview experience with Goldman Sachs for the SDE-2 (Associate Software Engineer) role:There was an online assessment and a phone screening round comprising of medium and hard DSA problems prior to the onsite rounds. The onsite interviews were interesting and different from traditional ones. Each round had two interviewers who actively cross-questioned me, so the pressure was a bit high.Onsite Round 1: DSA Round â€“ Two LeetCode medium problems + one follow-up question.Onsite Round 2: Software Engineering Practices Round â€“ This was the most interesting round. I was grilled on my current projects, HLD of rate limiting, different authentication strategies, REST vs GraphQL, JSON vs Protobuf, Java internals, and Java OOP concepts.Onsite Round 3: Design Round â€“ I was asked about the LLD of a flight booking service, database choice questions, and designing a service to validate millions of records from a text file (without using data processing frameworks like Spark). There were also questions on multithreading, concurrency, and Java.Onsite Round 4: Hiring Manager Round â€“ Focused on my resume, projects, and general behavioral questions.I felt I hadnâ€™t performed well, but to my surprise, I cleared all the rounds!In hindsight, what worked for me was:1. Staying calm and not panicking over unfamiliar questions.2. Even though I hadnâ€™t revised Java or design topics, I thought logically about what the correct behavior should be and answered accordingly.3. Most importantly, I treated each interview as a learning opportunity and turned them into engaging discussions.You either win or you learn!hashtag#interview hashtag#goldmansachs hashtag#softwareengineer
